title: USA vs Czech Republic   WSDC 2019
description:
The decision was a 3- 0 decision for the Czech Republic. 

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado
motion: This House would grant amnesty to perpetrators of crimes rather than seeking prosecution.

argument_units.text: ?? We live in a world where you have around 10 people in the streets of Chicago or New York holding a gun or with a lot of tattoos on their body, perhaps even holding certain weapons, but the police isn't currently authorized to look after them or prosecute them based on the law, that it is okay for them to be a part of gangs because there's no evidence that they have committed a crime we think that the importance and the purpose of the criminal justice system is to not just prosecute current crimes it is also to prevent and deter the occurrence and actions of crimes and we say on proposition that criminalizing gang membership is able to deter current crimes as well but also future crimes and we think that's the burden we have in this debate.

How do we define what a gang is? Three layers. First, is that we think the gang is when a member collectively identifies and adopts a group identity and they create an atmosphere of fear or intimidation. This could look like holding a lot of tattoos, Mr. Speaker, where you collectively identify through group tattoos or any kind of weapons or certain weapons or certain drugs. Secondly, we define what a gang is when the purpose is to literally pursue violence and a crime as a whole organization. And thirdly, we say that in the case that we criminalize gang membership and the police is able to prosecute certain members by identifying that they were part of a gang, we're happy to put them through extensive rehabilitation and at the moment in which they still don't have deep ties with the gang yet. In case that they are deeply involved with the gangs, we'll make sure that they go through rehabilitation and they're not part of gang culture such as in countries like America, and make sure that they cut absolutely every single tie with the gangs for the sake of crime.

With this in mind, I'm going to talk about three things. First, I'm going to talk about the criteria to criminalize. Secondly, I'm going to be talking about why this is a just and necessary policy. And thirdly, I'll be talking about why we decrease crime. Quickly, on terms of the criteria to criminalize, we say that if we prove this criteria applies for the sake of gang membership, we should take this debate. We think criminalization comes with two metrics. First, is that if we ensure that criminalization is able to deter the occurrence of crime. That's why, for instance, we criminalize guns in a lot of nations because we think that guns are deeply correlated with the actions of crimes, even when guns aren't literally the sake of crimes. But just because in terms of correlation, we think that when criminalization deters crime, we think that is okay. And secondly, we think it is important to protect the sustenance of society and make sure that society is a more safer and more sustainable place for innocent citizens to live on. If we prove that criminalizing gang membership is able to deter crime or prove that society is going to be a better place, we should take this debate. With this in mind, I'm going to talk about my positive manner.

First, let's talk about why this is a just and necessary policy. I have two layers in this argument. First, let me contextualize what gang members first do. We concede that membership does not equal violence, Mr. Speaker, but we say that gangs are inherently about committing violence and committing crimes. I think that the fact that you are trying to opt into this cycle and this organization of violence in and of itself is self-indicative of the fact that you are interested in crime, that you want to commit crimes or you want to steal someone or you want to brutally murder someone or you want to rape someone. I think the criminal justice system is there in order to prevent any incentive to commit crimes. And we think that on our side, it's more important to stop before actual casualties happen. How do we see this in the current status quo? It comes like we prevent strangers from looking around schools because just the fact that you might be a pedophile isn't necessary and trying to prevent it before any kind of pedophile takes action on the children in and of itself is important. Similarly, we think this is analogous to this motion because we say that in the case of gangs, we think just the fact that they were gangs is enough evidence that they're probably going to commit crimes in the future. And we want to prevent any kind of casualties from happening. We think that based on this we think we should win But second layer is that we think that in the many there's a many cases We're usually used or juveniles or course into this system given this We think our side is gonna be much better at preventing coercion Why is this because we think the coercion by force in it of itself is firstly an unjust principle That we should allow these people who are, who have the course by using this illegality and this criminalization as an excuse to prevent entering this gang in the first place. We think that given the youth and juveniles usually enter gangs because of this, just like mild nuance that like, Hey, being, being a part of a gang is cool, especially in countries like Mexico or Columbia, we are able to prevent this because we think that by the state in and of itself saying that gang membership is something illegal, that it is dangerous, we think that youth and juveniles, first of all, won't have any incentives to go on, but secondly, they won't be able to be coerced as much because these other gang members know that they themselves are in a predicament where they can be arrested and have their futures taken away. Given this, we think that it is just as necessary, because first, we have to prevent future crimes and deterrence. And I think that the fact that you are in a gang means that you're more likely to commit a crime than not doing so. Give me a second. And that the comparative is that it's too late on their side, because you can only arrest gangs at the moment in which they do commit a crime, where there are actual casualties, where there's going to be raped victims murdered victims or any kind of casualties in general taken all right so if so if you're going to say that criminalizing is going to be a deterrent why there are a lot of some drug smugglers or doing other like frauds even your minors and even you're going to be arrested if you did some of these kind of things. What do you think?

Let me talk about my case about why we decriminalized crime, and I'm pretty sure that's going to be self-explanatory. Two layers. First is that we actually reduced gangs in the first place. So first, I'd like to restate the purpose of taking this motion. So why we want to criminalize? It is not because we want to exile the criminals or the gangs from the society, but our purpose is to help those criminals or the gangs rehabilitate and get back to the normal society and the second purpose is to prevent the future crimes so um that is our purpose and um and also the opposition side said that the criteria for determining the gangs is vague however as the first piece of clearly explained, war gangs are, which is that the group, which is the gangs, we think that judge is also capable of determining whether a group belongs to the categorization of a gang.

And so next, I'd like to rebut to the position side's claim that this motion will not act as the deterrent. Well, even though the opposition side said so, as the first speaker clearly showed, there is a clear step that by taking this motion, gangs will decrease and then eventually the crime number will decrease. And even if we hypothesise that it will not have direct results, such as the decrease of the crime, we believe that it is very important for a country to clearly show their stance.

So currently the government's stance is very vague, and even though they criminalise the action that the gangs take, they haven't directly banned the gangs itself. However, as we all know, the police are always trying to disassemble those gangs by trying to find those crimes that they commit. So there's this contradiction between the government and the police. doesn't directly say that the gangs are out of law, the police is taking action that clearly shows that gangs is not under the law. And this is creating a confusion within the public, especially to the juvenile, as our first speaker briefly mentioned. Because the government is standing on an unstable and unclear stand, the public do not have this strong understanding that being a gang member is a crime. Because, well, we know that murdering someone is a crime without conscience, and there's no doubt within it. Because we know, because the government is clearly stating that it is a crime, it is a crime to kill someone. And so this will apply similarly to this case too. And by establishing this circumstance, we'll be able to decrease the number of youngs getting into the gangs because they think that being a gang member is cool. And also, it may be questionable whether a gang member actually committed a crime. Well, it is true that not every single member of gangs does not commit crime. However, if we compare the possibility of committing crime between a gang member and a non-gang member, no, and as I first, as I clearly stated in the first, in the beginning of my speech, our purpose is to prevent the future crimes. So for these reasons, we propose this motion. Thank you.

That is, that they failed in providing a counterfactual. We think the moment in which they failed to provide a counterfactual, they lost this debate.

I'm going to be talking about two issues. First is about the bulk of their argument, which was about this metric of what a gang is. Secondly, I'm going to be talking about which side is able to prevent the occurrence of crimes. And I'm going to be talking about this in a couple of layers. First, in terms of metric, opposition fundamentally failed in explaining

The fact that they didn't respond to this is a concession that these gangs are dangerous and that we have to stop them and they concede that in the case of violent gangs it is necessary to criminalize gang membership. We think that if you want to just clean up rooms, it's much better on the counterfactual. Where on our side, we're still going to provide things like regulated government offices where if you want to clean up stuff, you can enter the Red Cross or UNICEF. And I think this is much better on their side, regardless of what incentive there is. It's better than some unregulated, potential dangerous, unorganized group. We think that counterfactual is good. The reason why we are able to criminalize gangs, even if it is vague, because we think on our side, we include courts in the equation of criminalization, which opposition absolutely neglected. Just in the same way that we have to look at incentive, and we prosecute attempted murder, and not murder, but the intent of committing murder is in and of itself important. So the incentive of committing crimes is enough reason of criminalizing. So the incentive of committing crimes is enough reason of criminalizing gang membership in the first place. Therefore, we think that their whole argument is false. Let's look at the more important question then. Occurrence of crime.

Firstly, we think that in the counterfactual, gangs are going to exist. Given that gangs are going to Firstly, we think that in the counterfactual, gangs are going to exist. Or just imagine an organization of like scammers, of a gang that only commits to use some burglaries to enter a very important like finance company, we think like Golden Sacks, right? We think that's bad because companies have a certain right to know that they have to protect other employees who are not gangs. And on their side, we think that it's simply, we think that it's good that companies do know if they're gangs or not, because that's literally the point of criminalization, right? To ensure the benefit of society. They weren't able to engage with this. However, let's say that we still want these criminals to employ these ex-convicts, right? Why is this better on our side? Because we think just in the same way we do for juvenile, we could just hide their identity up. That is, that we don't allow criminal companies to give access to criminal records. And on our side, we're telling you that we're going to give rehab, job training, and community sentencing. We think this is more than enough incentive for companies to employ them in the first place. They weren't able to give a counterfactual. And thirdly, I'm going to prove to you why on their side, they aren't able to have effective

rehabilitation. Why is this the case? Because under their side, when these gang members enter prison, they're still deeply tied with gangs. That is, that they have to stay with gangs to survive, especially in countries like America or Colombia, where most prison inmates are usually gang members. So they're forced to hold ties with gangs. They're forced into a community of hatred and violence. And we think just in terms of broken window theory, which is that if you are in a community of violence, you're more likely to commit violence. title: WSDC 2018 SF: China VS England
description:
Semi-finals (impromptu):

This House believes that rehabilitation should be the only consideration in criminal sentencing.

Team China won against Team England unanimously (7:0).
motion: This House Prefers Rehabilitation Over Retribution in Criminal Sentencing.

argument_units.text: In his book Crime and Punishment, Fyodor Dostoevsky said that prisons are the universities of crime.

Because in the status quo, prisoners are stuck in a system where they have to join gangs in order to survive in prisons. Where they stay in cramped cells next to murderers and rapists who believe that the state has failed them. This is the result of a system that prioritizes retribution and deterrence. Two systems that say that harsh punishment are the only ways in order you can get successful outcomes in a system. We stand against that. We want to change the system.
We believe that rehabilitation is the only just way of sentencing. What are our steps? Three parts. First, we support rehabilitation as the only consideration of criminal sentencing.

What is rehabilitation? Rehabilitation is a system that uses methods like community-based sentencing to prioritize turning criminals with ill intent into functioning members of society afterwards. This works like systems like the Criminon Rehabilitation Program in the United States, which saw a 0% recidivism rate after it was implemented. Generally speaking, we envision decreased sentence lengths and will prioritize helping criminals instead. Secondly, we concede that we will not solve all problems of justice. However, we believe that the stigma of criminalization levied on criminals will eventually disappear. Finally, we will provide the same services, i.e. psychological counseling and community-based sentencing, to those people who have not yet committed crimes as a way of proactively stopping people from turning towards injustice.
We're going to forward two arguments. First, why rehabilitation is the only just way of sentencing, and secondly, where we'd better tackle crime.

First, on justice. We think that the majority... I want to begin this argument by characterizing the vast majority of instances as to what causes crime. Because the vast majority of crimes are results of these structural failures of the state. Where in almost every part of the world, the majorities of crimes are crimes of acquisition, like stealing, stealing. And that's a result of you being poor. And the reason why you being poor. And the reason why you are poor is because the state does not provide you with the adequate resources for you to have the basic standard of living. That's why in nations like the U.S., they see the over-criminalization of poor African Americans, and where 88% of crimes within that state are crimes of acquisition. Therefore, the state has failed you in the position of basic resources. And because of that, the state has an obligation to provide you with the reparations, the education, and the opportunities that have to apply to you, and that happens through rehabilitation and informed reparations. Why is this important? It is because the moment at which you are born into a state, the state gives you a promise. Because a sacrifice of rights in terms of taxation, for example, and this is a reciprocal responsibility to provide you that fair and basic standard of living. Secondly, we don't think that Team England is going to come up here and talk about murder and rape in terms of heinous instances of crime. But recognize that even in those instances, the vast majority of violent crime are correlated to these same reasons. Because in the lack of alternatives, you default to things like gangs in Chicago, where drug violence is rampant, and to the streets of Rio de Janeiro and Brazil, where crime is also a violation of justice. They might stand for a soft mix of rehabilitation law and other forms of justice, but note that the consideration of other measurement prevents rehabilitation from operating at its maximum capacity. Two reasons why. First of all, countervailing considerations damage the effectiveness of rehab. Because when you add other considerations, such as retribution or deterrence, no thank you, that's when rehabilitation becomes so optimal. Because when you add things like retribution, which extends sentencing claims to suboptimal things that are beyond the time necessary to be successful in rehabilitation, and you spend more on the prison infrastructure, money that could be going to more successful rehabilitation programs, that's when rehabilitation becomes far more unsuccessful, given that it's a most just system of publishing. But secondly, note that all these considerations are oppositional towards the efficacy of rehabilitation. Deterrence, for example, values things like extreme punishment to prevent future crime. So take the example of a criminal who goes through anger management exercises under a form of rehabilitation. But because deterrence still exists on their side of the house, they have to go back into the prison cells and stay back and watch the prison fights and room with prisoners that believe that the state has failed them. That decreases and diminishes the effectiveness of this justice system on their side. We think there's only a prismally justified metric of punishment. If prisons are so bad, then why do you support sending people there for any medical time? Okay, Steve, the prison's bad in the status quo. That's why we're forming the system to emphasize some other metric of it to make it more effective, that's what I was thinking.

All right, next argument, as to why we better take down crime. I first want to characterize to you the purpose of the criminal justice system, i.e., the reason why the state creates things like courts and prisons are to protect individuals and to optimize social outcomes by decreasing the occurrences of crime. And this is also for victims, if they want to talk about victims, be just, because a world in which we optimize the justice system is one where victims feel safe in. The problem is their system values the draconian and archaic system of justice, because the draconian system of retribution is a misconception that this is the only way to punish people. A system that violates the human rights of individuals. And this is also a system that is incredibly ineffective, which is why one-sixth of the crime in the United States is done by repeat offenders. This is due to two structural reasons of their assignment of the House. First of all, note that prisons and the environment that it creates perpetuates crime. Because the environment that you're in are people who have committed heinous acts like murder and rape. So you have to join things like gangs. That's the only way to protect yourself in this heinous position. You are next to murderers and rapists who tell you and for their narratives of mistrust against the state. This is a community of anger. And this is also bad, because in places where they have this retributive system, recidivism rates, i.e. occurring committee crimes after you have been involved in crime, increases, which is why retributive systems have failed in Uruguay, USA, Honduras, and France. This is an archaic system that fails in their obligations to protect people. But secondly, know that when people get out of prison, a post-prime role is suboptimal to minimizing crime. Why is this the case? Because there is a stigma against prisoners. That when you are an ex-convict and you're trying to get a job, and you have the stigma of a prisoner standing on your resume, you do not get employment, and you do not get a job to to get decent living standards, which turns people to more crime. We solve this through three reasons on our side of the house. First of all, one, intuitively, we solve the root issue of crime. So things like not having an economic stability can be solved through drug trade. Things like being not being able to turn to, forcing to turn to things like drugs can be solved through drug rehabilitation. I mean, that's comparatively better. Secondly, you get people to live better lives through things like community-based sentencing, means that you're able to treat these people in a far more humane way, and tells people that they can be integrated into society. And note that there are still deterrents on the outside of the house, because when you put under things like house arrest, your freedoms are still stripped away from you, and we think that's a suboptimal rule which any prisoner, or any rational individual would not prefer. But finally, outside of prison, when you implement a rehabilitative system, it is better for the comparative because you reduce the stigma against these prisoners. The fault in the status quo is the perception that this justice system has created, that the only way to punish criminals is to be retributed in deterrent systems, to strip them of their rights, to tell society that these are people not deserving of human rights. That's why they're not being hired. We shift that on our side of the house, to dehumanize criminals, that they are deserving of human rights, that they are bidding for integration, which is why we prioritize a system of justice. So, the justice is a just system of punishing, because we better reduce crime on our side of the, you should go to side proposition. Thank you.

They claim to care about the perception of African Americans and of minorities who are viewed as, in their identity, inherently linked to this crime. And that is evil human beings. I'm going to be doing two things in my speech. title: WSDC 2024 R2 - Japan vs Syria
description:
This House Prefers A World where Truth and Reconciliation Commissions were established to deal with the aftermath of the Yugoslav Wars rather than the ICTY.

3-0 Japan Wins
motion: This House Prefers Truth and Reconciliation Commissions (TRCs) Over the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTY).

argument_units.text: The brutality of the Yugoslav war left us with an aftermath that can only be characterized as individuals losing access to basic social and economic rights, fragile peace that lacks sustainability, and people not knowing where their loved ones are after the chaos of the war has unveiled. Instead of prioritizing the reconciliation of the region and the rehabilitation of the most vulnerable in the region, we see the ICTY to fully focus and fixate on the weakest form of quote-unquote justice, which is the punitive form. We stand for a more effective form of justice, a more reformative form of justice. We also value the betterment of civil society, incredibly proud to propose.

Before I get into my argumentation, a few points of framing and setup. First, what does our world look like? Our world is one where there are eight national TRCs in each country within the Yugoslavian region. They report back to one regional TRC. These TRCs are going to be implemented by a local decree with the help and support of the UN, similar to Syria and Union. Those TRCs are going to be non-judicial internal bodies created from the people and not to the people.

We see those TRCs to be made out of three fundamental committees. The first is one that receives and processes applications for amnesty and conducting public hearings. The second is one that is responsible for compensating and rehabilitating victims of the war and the most vulnerable, similar to the R&R within South Africa. And the third and final one is a committee that is responsible for giving out recommendations. Recommendations in three different ways. The first is recommendations of reparation actions to be adopted by the UN and local governments that seek to help and reconciliate. The second is recommendations of prosecutions to national courts. And thirdly, publishing a joint historical record every two or three years to continuously update the historical record of the war and to not miss any details of atrocities or crimes that are committed.

Second idea is, what are the conditions of the amnesty that will be given or asked of the House? We see three conditions. First, full disclosure on all atrocities or crimes committed and or witnessed. Secondly, the crimes that are committed will have to be politically motivated. An individual has to have a certain level of authority forcing him to do that crime in order for amnesty to be valid and to be granted in the first place. Thirdly and finally, agreeing on doing public hearings and giving our testimonies to the public and giving the public full access to the testimonies that are given by individuals who got amnesty. Thirdly, we think that the implementation of those TRCs is likely to

be effective on our side of the House because of local and presidential decree, funds and administrative power that is given by the UN, and the fact that the commissioners of the TRC in the first place are likely to be individuals who are civil society leaders, are likely to be experts of diplomacy and reconciliation. Fourthly and finally is the fact that the kind of justice that we're explicitly following and pursuing on our side of the house is a reformative type of justice and not the punitive kind that ICTY supports. Our stand is victim-oriented. We don't think that victims get justice when they see a leader who's committed multiple genocides being put behind bars for eight years. We don't think that that's the kind of justice that victims seek on our side of the house. When it comes to argumentation, three arguments. First, on how TRCs lead to better victim satisfaction. Secondly, on how we establish peace in the region. Thirdly and finally, on how TRCs on our side of the house achieve better governance in the region. When it comes to the first argument, we prove this in three ways. The first idea is compensation and access to mental health facilities. It's very important to know for a fact that the incentives of the UN to participate in the region will likely remain the same on our side of the house. We see any kind of financial support from the UN to be reallocated towards establishing the necessary facilities and to provide mental health support for victims and individuals who are most vulnerable of the war and we also see direct financial compensation being given to such people. Secondly, we see scores from NGOs and donors because of more information that we get through accessing more testimonies, because we are able to record and report on more atrocities and crimes that are likely to happen, we accumulate records for such crimes and atrocities that happen, we get a better understanding and a better record on what actually happened, this is fundamentally important because it gets the region more attention from NGOs who will likely support the civil society. And with the fact that we get victim testimonies and the fact that we allow victims to access the necessary platform in the first place to share their stories and to share these experiences, this mobilizes individuals that are more sympathetic on our side of the house to support these individuals and to support the region and to donate to it and to volunteer in the region in a way that is supportive and in a way that benefits the most vulnerable. And also, the supportive NGOs will likely be more effective on our side of the house, no thank you, will likely be more effective on our side of the house because of the recommendations and records that are likely to be given be more effective on our side of the house

because of the recommendations and records that are likely to be given by TRCs on our side of the house. Any NGO that wants to support and be active in supporting the region on our side of the house will have access to information and will have access to more details that is likely to help them and make the allocation of their resources to be fundamentally more effective on our side of the house. The impact of this analysis is that we get better approach towards healing generational trauma and establishing more efficiency in managing resources in the first place and allocating them more effectively towards empowering the civil society.
Before I move on to my next mechanism, go on.
PRC relies on a passive system where perpetrators have to willingly come out and apologize. Why will it work specifically in the context of Yugoslavia?

We think that perpetrators will come out and choose to take the amnesty because they fear to be prosecuted in the first place. They see this as an opportunity to alleviate some of the prosecution that might likely happen to them. We see incentives for them to participate in the TRC to take amnesties and to give out testimony so that they do escape prosecution. Second idea on a more accurate historical record, we have more witnesses on our side of the house that are testifying from civilians and victims because they do have the incentives on our side of the house to participate because of things like A, platform that is not available in the ICTY, not everybody can actually go, not all victims can go and testify in the ICTY, not every individual has access to such platforms. B, the opportunities to face the perpetrator and actually tell the story and actually have the perpetrator acknowledge the suffering that they have caused to them. C, access to compensation that is likely to only be granted in case of testifying and actually going out and speaking in the TRC. And finally, the fact that we actually build more momentum to testify because once individuals who were fit of prosecution choose to step up and testify in the first place, we see that people on the ground are likely to become more committed and to get a certain level of momentum towards giving out testimonies, they themselves, which will get us more valuable testimonies because these individuals or people on the ground are more quantity in testimony than the first place. This means that we establish a better joint historical record in the first place that is likely to be written which will help which will help reconciliating experts and will give us the necessary perspective of different victims and different perpetrators. The second idea is that we actually get less toxic nationalism and media war. Less toxic nationalism because we actually now have better education because we give people a better historical record on what actually happened. We focus more on heroic stories that actually show some initiatives of soldiers, for example, who are supportive to minorities or who are supportive to victims in the region. And we also get better testimonies that give us a better collective image on what actually happened. But what is fundamentally one of the biggest failures of the ICTY is the fact that they failed to manage the media war. On their side of the house, they have narratives that say that Slobodan Milizavich is a hero. On their side of the house they have narratives that say that these individuals are actually not the perpetrators but are actually the victim. Each country within the region is saying no we're victims, they're victimizing themselves but they're not willing to accept the fact that they were perpetrators at a certain point. Second argument is on the fact on how we establish better peace in the region. Because of the joint historical record that we get on our side of the house, by focusing on journalism and public hearing, on our side of the house, soldiers will only kill and commit crimes, and do things that are detrimental if they're incredibly pushed to do so. On our side of the house, we have less soldiers who have the mindset of going out and simply obliterating individuals against them because they do understand that to a certain extent they too are perpetrators and not only the victims in the case. This means that we get more possibility of peace talks, especially because of the social pressure that is likely to manifest on our side of the house as we're seeing a shift in democracy in the region after the war. Over 200 political parties were established after the war and with the less toxic nationalism that's produced on our side of the house, we bring more possibility for diplomatic and peace talks, war is used as we are proud to propose.

Justice is a prerequisite to reconciliation, not an alternative. We are extremely proud to oppose. I'll do a few things in my speech. First, I'll talk about characterization. Second, some responses to the Prime Minister. And third, I'll forward two arguments from Team Japan.

First, on why we better achieve justice for victims. And second, on the achievement of regional stability. Before argumentation, I want to note a few things on praying we do not agree with. We think there are three major differences between the ICTY and the hypothetical TRC we must note. First, on the existence of punishment. The ICTY's main goal was to persecute the most important leaders who spearheaded the war. On the flip, the TRC's goal was to move on. They almost always granted amnesty to war criminals, meaning this TRC was also systematically unable to persecute individuals. Secondly, on who has authority in each of these institutions. The ICTI was created and is controlled by the UN to ensure fairness. It was established outside the region by a third party. The TRC on the other hand is created more locally, often by the new government. In this specific scenario, it would be difficult to choose where to place the TRC, but the point is it would be done inside Yugoslavia. Thirdly, on the budget, the ICTI had a massive budget incomparable of that to the TRC, reaching ten times the budget of most TRCs. That being said, I want to make a few engagements with the PM and disprove their claims. On the first thing, they talked in their characterization as how this is going to work miraculously, where you're going to place different TRCs in eight different countries and we're going to have one main TRC that's going to work. However, I don't agree with this because they never, I'm confused by this on two levels. Firstly, this is not going to work, right? There's no incentive for a Serbian to go to a Croatian TRC and confess. You're seen as a traitor by all your friends and family. You have to get on a plane, travel miles to Croatia just to apologize. But secondly, and most importantly, the perpetrators are literally in other countries, right? I don't see how this is going to work. This needs to be explained better. The second response I have, their first argument is about better victim satisfaction. I have two problems with this argument. Firstly, they never answer why people will come and testify in the first place. Their only response is that they want to escape persecution. But the fact is that when people do not come and confess in TRCs, they often get away with it with no punishment. Look at South Africa, look at other cases of TRCs. These individuals are the most vulnerable in this debate, these individuals get no justice in proposition. This alone is debate winning. But finally, the second clash on peace is obviously going to our bench because they concede to us in this debate that leaders being in power is bad. And we prove to you from an unengaged argumentation why these leaders can uniquely be ousted in our vote. A late supposed justice is a justice denied.

So I'm going to do the three main questions in this debate. First of all, who helps the victims more? First point of clarification, they told us that the NGOs are symmetrical. title: WSDC 2022 | Quarter Final | Sri Lanka v Canada
description:
The speakers have been assigned a position randomly and the speech does not necessarily reflect their view.

Canada (proposition) v Sri Lanka (opposition)

This motion has an infoslide:
Criminal trials typically end in one of two verdicts - "guilty" or "not guilty". Under Scots law there exists a third verdict -"not proven". This is typically used to indicate the jury or judge believe the defendant could potentially be guilty, but there is not sufficient evidence to convict. In a "not proven" verdict, the prosecutor has the option to retry a case, while this is not possible in a "not guilty" decision. 

The motion reads:
THP a world in which juries/judges can use a "not proven" verdict in criminal courts, in addition to "guilty" and "not guilty" verdicts.
motion: This House Prefers a world in which juries/judges can use a "not proven" verdict in criminal courts, in addition to "guilty" and "not guilty" verdicts.

argument_units.text: within any given case justice is gray ambiguous and murky but opposition shoehorns justice and the criminal justice system into a stark black and white binary this discrepancy has called assaulters to walk free on technicality in the world of opposition, and innocent Black teenagers to be ruled guilty on emotion and on prejudice. In the world of proposition, we acknowledge the time, investigation, and precision it takes to obtain justice. A swift binary cannot account for that. Imprecise justice is permanent injustice.
Canada has three arguments to forward in this debate. First, on legal precision. Second, on the innocent. And thirdly and finally, on plea deals and initial speech. But before that,

what is our stance? Two parts. Number one, this is a fact. Most legal systems make retrying a not guilty verdict very difficult or impossible entirely in the status quo. This is called double jeopardy, where you're tried for the same charge you were acquitted of, which emerged when there was less criticism of institutions and greater fear of government tyranny, meaning that any mistrial was assumed in their world to be perverse and unjust. What this means then is that double jeopardy and retrying a case after a not guilty verdict is near impossible in the world of opposition. Second, to retry a not proven case in our world, there's likely some high bar that a

judge has to evaluate. For instance, via a preliminary hearing where prosecutors must show that new evidence has come about or some mistake was made in the original trial. What this means then is that this is very similar to current preliminary hearings that screen for sufficient evidence. Not every single trial is going to be retried. We think there are incentives on the parts of prosecutors to only retry cases with new evidence or evidence that would change the outcome of a trial. With that out of the way, first argument on legal

precision. There are many cases in many trials in opposition's world where there's legitimate moral and legal ambiguity over whether or not someone is guilty, not guilty, or innocent. In these cases, which are separate parts of the argument, either A, the trial concludes that the person is not guilty when there's legal ambiguity over the availability of evidence about witness testimonies, the truth, and et cetera. Or B, in a separate case, ambiguity leads to the jury deciding that someone is guilty on racial class biases, on these inherent biases, and a segment of emotion. I first want to talk about the former set of cases where a not guilty verdict is reached due to moral and legal ambiguity.

Why do these cases happen? There's two structural reasons. Structural reason number one is that the criminal justice system often enters trials prematurely and quite quickly. This is true because A, the justice system is criminally overburdened and overstaffed. Judges and justices have too many cases on their docket. They want to get through these cases quickly so that an accused person isn't in jail forever and their lawyer doesn't get mad. B, public defenders are often juggling between dozens of cases on a daily basis, and not to mention they're quite underfunded and intercept. But moreover, prosecutors, DAs, ADAs have electoral and timeframe incentives to tally as many verdicts as possible. They're often in competition for a reelection or appointment when it comes to prosecutors and district authorities. They often have a limited number of years that they can serve in their time frame and their electoral frame, which means they want to squeeze cases in. The last reason why trials are often rushed and overburdened on their side of the house is that the police often face mounting public pressure to get criminals off the streets. These people generally care about their safety. They care about the community that they live in and the children that they care about, which leads to police forces pursuing a promising piece of evidence in the world of

opposition, even though it could lead to moral ambiguity in a case where you don't actually create a precise verdict. The second reason why trials are rushed on their side of the house, and I'm willing to take a POI after this, is that evidence is often unavailable, tampered with, or inadmissible. There's a range of situations where a not guilty verdict is reached, not because the person is genuinely innocent. In some sets of cases, the police might mislabel a piece of evidence, for instance, or fail to meet a court timeline to bring up a piece of evidence in discovery. In other cases, a key piece of evidence might be missing. There's not enough time for the police or the public to procure it, such as a dead body, for instance. But in other cases, the witnesses don't want to come forward, or it's the case that they might be a victim of witness intimidation, and they don't want to come forward in this particular time frame. The implication of all of the above framing is that there's a large margin and a large set of morally ambiguous cases where a not guilty verdict is reached out of convenience and moral ambiguity. We fix this. Why is this the case? First of all, police and prosecutors in our set of house can learn from their mistakes. They can meet deadlines that haven't been met in previous trial, and they can reframe their case since they now have time to look at strategy. Second of all, time allows for more evidence to be collected. There's a range of situations in which this is true. Witnesses

might come forward after a not proven guilty when they otherwise wouldn't because they feel guilty that they could have actually provided evidence. A body might be found three years later by a hiker, for instance. There might be new methods of investigation. And given that this is a retrospective motion, they have to deal with DNA evidence being introduced a few decades ago at the turn of the century, which overturned a number of cases. NDAs might expire on their side of the house, which is an additional reason why time allows for more evidence to be collected. Part two of the argument then. But before I go on to part two, I'm willing to take a PY. If new witnesses come forward or new evidence is discovered or brought before the jury, then we can simply request a retrial on the basis that new evidence has come to light. Why is a not proven verdict necessary in order to take this evidence into account? So we already told you in point one that for a variety of reasons, the state is subjugating you.

Retrials are often very rare or even impossible in some jurisdictions in your world. But I think there are other structural reasons that I'll touch on in part two of the argument. Part two of the argument, on the set of cases where a guilty verdict is reached.

In many cases where there's lots of ambiguity over someone committed a crime, there is a default onto a guilty verdict. This is especially horrible since in these cases where jurors feel a pressure to reach a verdict, they want to go home, they want to go back to their job since juror compensation is low, they want to go back to their family and actually scroll on social media since they're often sequestered in isolated places. In these cases where pressure is high to reach a verdict, juries often resort to their gut instincts, their emotions, their perceptions, their inherent biases, and their racial biases. The fact that a 17-year-old Black youth on their side of the house is probably guilty because of the gut feeling and the fact that this juror wants to go home. We fix this on our side of the house because these are individuals who aren't fully convinced on this person's guilt. These are morally righteous individuals who have some racial tendencies and some racial biases, but out of convenience will cast a guilty ballot on their side of the house. These are individuals who are given a third option on our side of the house who do not need to resort to these emotional and racial biases. The weighing of this argument is simple. Number one, in principle, we should care about legal and moral precision. The criminal justice system is a violent arm of the state that holds a monopoly over violence over us. They can lock us into jail. They can take away our possessions and sequester us from our family and friends. It is the state's responsibility to determine guilt and non-guilt precisely because of the violation and because of the moral tyranny the state holds over us. Second of all, since this is a retrospective case, we have already proven in the above analysis that there's a lot of cases where moral ambiguity

doesn't exist on arson in the house, where new evidence comes up, where you don't have to declare mistrial, where you can do things like reframe the strategy of a prosecutorial case. This is why this argument is important. Second argument then on the innocent. Even in cases where people are genuinely innocent, these people are deemed guilty in the court of public opinion. This is true for a number of reasons. Number one, in the process of being convicted, the trial is thus unpublished, the mugshot of a criminal is out there, and people often internalize the fact that this person is someone who is guilty. This is often worse than media sensationalization, where the media wants to portray this criminal as hardened and battle-hardened. Second of all, the average person understands that if someone is not proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, they often cast a non-guilty. There's a very high bar for guilt, which is why people, for safety reasons and self-protection reasons, err on the side of caution and assume that this individual is a guilty person. We've missed this structurally because individuals who are certain over their guilt can be free from an employer who assumes guilt, can be free from a neighbor, for instance, who doesn't want a relationship with them, because these are individuals who are genuinely innocent, who are exonerated from the court of public opinion. In both sides of the house, innocent people face ambiguity, but on our side, many people are truly exonerated when there's this third option for morally ambiguous cases. This means that on our side of the house, these individuals who are genuinely innocent can get a job, can get a relationship, and that doesn't occur in the world of opposition. Imprecise justice is permanent injustice.
We welcome the first speaker of the opposition. Hi, just checking I can, be always in chat. Both sides of this debate agree that the criminal justice system in most countries is extremely
burdened in terms of its monetary cost, in terms of human capital, in terms of physical space.

I want to immediately clarify at the top of this debate, in terms of threshold and their misunderstanding of the criminal justice system's incentives. Because in status quo, the threshold for criminal conviction is guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. This is because, as they say, we recognize the punishment is so secure and recognize the lifetime stigma that comes about with an individual getting a guilty verdict which is why the justice system in status quo believes in innocent until proven guilty. On proposition even though a person may not go to jail they still lower the threshold for an individual to get a verdict that is anything except for a not guilty verdict by providing this third option. We think that what this third option does is maintain all the stigma of a guilty verdict without any of the ability to hold this or for this individual to get some sort of redress. That is the harm here. On counterfactual, I want to make it clear that calling for a mistrial exists on our side of the house. So if there has been a tainting of evidence, a problem with the jury, you can throw evidence out and reconsider evidence and redo the trial. This is because by the time you come to a verdict, you have to assume that all evidence has been considered. On proposition, even if there is no change to the evidence itself, they are still fine with retrying a case. On our side of the house, if new evidence is brought up, you can always bring that case up again with new witnesses. And this isn't just limited to prosecutors as they would have you claim. There are bunches of instances in mass majority of instances where this is done by defendants look at the innocence project for example that seeks to do this three quick points

of rebuttal before i move into argumentation firstly on stance i want to make it clear that this debate is not just retrospective it is retrospective but it's also about the future because it's a preferred motion secondly their problem with double jeopardy isn't really a problem. We think that the presence of the double jeopardy principle is a good thing because it is that that prevents abuse by the state. It is that that prevents an individual who has been deemed not guilty from constantly being put back into trial where there is no new evidence brought up to create some sort of doubt. Second response is as to their argument on the two instances of a trial. First, we consider resource limitation in the instance where they say in non-guilty verdicts there's trial rushed, but you don't get rid of that overburdening of the system on their side of the house. We will prove through argumentation that it gets much, much worse. All their problems with missing evidence can be accounted for in a mistrial, but we think that they concede ambiguity here. We will thus prove in argumentation that it is better when ambiguous for an individual to get a not guilty verdict than it is for them to get a not proven verdict. Second, in terms of the second group of instances where people are considered guilty by default, second, the response is that this simply isn't untrue. This goes against the incentives of the justice system, which is to ensure that people have a very high bar for being considered guilty. But if we're able to prove that biases get worse on proposition, we're able to get rid of all of the analysis. The second argument very clearly clashes with my second, so I'll deal with it there and do the weighing there. Before my argumentation go. When a non-guilty verdict is reached, the police close cases and stop searching

for evidence to maximize resources, which is important because the police has access to superior technology in crime scenes. Why are cases on your side of the house likely to be reopened because of a discovery of evidence? Because evidence is always going to be found later down the line. You yourself conceded that when new technology like DNA finding came about, that we were able to find new evidence. That in and of itself is a concession that you're always able to get new evidence.

I'd also concede, I'd also want to point out that police don't have an incentive to disclose cases as soon as the trial is done. They also have an incentive to bring up those cases because it's good for their reputation. First argument as to why this leads to less fair trials on their side

of the house. I want to make it clear that jurors have preconceived notions of dependence even if you lack sufficient evidence. This is because of subconscious bias regarding an individual's race or religion, media bias that wants to do things like fear-monger, the fact that people overestimate their own abilities to intuit a person's guilt. On our side of the house, juries cannot act upon these biases for three reasons. One, they have to rationalize their decision when they present it to the court in terms of coming to a conclusion. Second, jury selection is done by lawyers in order to ensure that there is a prevention of bias within jurors. Three, there are checking mechanisms to ensure that any form of egregious bias within a court is taken out. For example, you're able to get rid of a juror if they exhibit some sort of bias, which means there is no ability to deem an individual guilty on our side of the house if they lack evidence, and it is more than likely that they are going to be considered not guilty. On their side of the house, what they do is introduce a third option. What does this mean? In an instance where there is a lack of evidence, you allow juries to use their own intuition to justify gaps and bump up an individual's verdict from not guilty to not proven and they are able to do this because they are able to rationalize this by saying we don't have the evidence but it is likely that this person is guilty. I feel that this person is guilty. Therefore, we're going to bump them up from not guilty to not proven. Prosecutors also have an incentive to do this on their side of the house because bumping up the verdict from not guilty to not proven betters their own reputation. So they are more likely to appeal to these biases, such as racial biases and ethnic biases. The conclusion of this argument is that more people are likely to be racially profiled and receive a not proven verdict where they would otherwise get a not guilty verdict. This is bad because in most cases if you lack evidence it more than likely means the person is innocent. If witnesses are unsure if it was the same person, if you cannot find evidence like bloody footprints, it is more than likely considered that that person is innocent. This is an instance where there is a state failure. The state has a duty to collect all the evidence it can and prosecute this person. It is unjustified to punish the accused on the basis that the state is unable to do its job. But we think this hurts the underprivileged the most because there is likely to be a double standard. A white person with a not proven verdict is likely to be seen as innocent, but as a black person with a not proven verdict is more likely to be seen as guilty, preventing them from doing things like accessing job opportunities. On our side of the house, when you have a not guilty verdict for both a black and white person, it is much harder for those racial biases to seep out in employment. title: WSDC 2022 | Quarter Final | Malaysia v China
description:
The speakers have been assigned a position randomly and the speech does not necessarily reflect their view.

Malaysia (proposition) v China (opposition)

This motion has an infoslide:
Criminal trials typically end in one of two verdicts - "guilty" or "not guilty". Under Scots law there exists a third verdict -"not proven". This is typically used to indicate the jury or judge believe the defendant could potentially be guilty, but there is not sufficient evidence to convict. In a "not proven" verdict, the prosecutor has the option to retry a case, while this is not possible in a "not guilty" decision. 
The motion reads:
THP a world in which juries/judges can use a "not proven" verdict in criminal courts, in addition to "guilty" and "not guilty" verdicts.
motion: This House Would Introduce a "Not Proven" Verdict in Criminal Trials.

title: Final WSDC 2017
motion: This House Supports restrictions on free speech to combat the rise of right-wing populism.

argument_units.text: Ladies, gentlemen, fellow wizards, muggles. Right-wing populist parties, individuals and activists worldwide are a threat to minorities and to democracies. Side government solves this problem.

What are our definitions in this debate? We think courts should decide if these are right-wing populists using five criteria. The first is nativism, i.e. the scapegoating of immigrants and ethnic minorities. The second is hostility towards elites, particularly institutions like media and the courts. The third is excessive authoritarian approach to law and order. The fourth is a disregard for political correctness and truth. And the fifth, and crucially, is that because of a desire to appeal to a broad coalition of disaffected individuals, spanning the socio-political divide and often with different political desires, they often have a shallow policy agenda designed to appeal to as many people as possible. What does it look like? It looks like Trump in the US, Duterte in the Philippines, the AFD in Germany.

What's our model for dealing with these individuals and groups? We would institute a range of restrictions on free speech of political parties and their activists. That goes from shutting down websites and individuals which advocate on their behalf, like Breitbart or Milo Yiannopoulos, to not providing them with a platform, not reporting on them in the media or allowing them to speak in town hall events, to not providing them with a platform, not reporting on them in the media or allowing them to speak in town hall events, to banning them from social media, or, in some instances, being happy to ban them from contesting elections entirely. We think that's an extension of the precedent set in the banning of the neo-Nazi party in Germany and of states around the world in banning hate speech. We would note that while the unique phenomenon of right-wing populism is a problem today, we're a similar problem to arise with left-wing populism. We would support this policy there too.

We have two burdens in this debate. The first is to show you that this policy is justified. And the second is to show you that this is an effective way of dealing with the danger that right-wing populists present. With that in mind, we're bringing you three arguments. The first is that we combat the threat to minorities. The second is that this harms the development of solutions to the problems which lead to right-wing populists coming about at all. And the third, in Ed's speech, is how this is a fundamental affront to democracy. Before I move on to my first argument about how we actually combat the threat to minorities, what are the principal parameters within which this debate takes place? Two things. The first is that democracy necessitates a balance of rights, because the rights of individuals sometimes contradict each other. My right to wave my wand in the air contradicts Kenza's right not to get poked in the eye. We believe that protecting the most vulnerable from physical harm weighs up more than the ability of certain individuals to have freedom of speech. I'm going to be dealing with that principally in my speech. The second principal parameter, which this debate takes place within, is that democracy can only happen if it's truth-led. When you are anti-truth, you forfeit your right to the protections of free speech. Ed's going to be talking to you about that principally in his speech.

Before I move on to my first argument about how we combat the threat to minorities, what exactly is this one characteristic that is so exclusive to right-wing populism? Wouldn't you end up banning a lot of other ideologies that have similar characteristics? OK, we told you that courts are good at deciding whether things and individuals fall into certain categories. We gave you literally five characteristics that define right-wing populist movements. If courts decide that an individual or a group is part of that movement, then they'll ban those movements, then they'll institute these kinds of free speech protections. Not sure what they're getting at there. On to my first argument, which is about how we combat the threat to minority groups. Because right-wing populism thrives on riling people up and channeling their anger. That's because right-wing populists are overwhelmingly problem and not solution-oriented. Why? Because the reason that they're so popular is that they're able to appeal to diverse coalitions of individuals, often with very little in common. Someone living in a trailer park in northern Florida has basically nothing in common with a soccer mum living in the Midwest, but they're united by being broadly disaffected with the status quo. The policy demands of these people, economically and socially, are very different. So, in order to maintain this coalition, right-wing populists do two things. Firstly, they promise very shallow things. They have very unspecific policies or unsubstantiated catch-all magic wand policies. Secondly, they focus on the problems that their followers face as opposed to the solutions which divide them. In an attempt to flatten the causes of these problems into something which can nominally easily be solved, they often blame minority groups for all of these issues. That means drug dealers in the Philippines, Mexicans in the US, Moroccans in the Netherlands are blamed for all of the problems which the followers of populists face. The reason that blaming minorities leads to increased violence is threefold. The first is that they take the anger that individuals have and they direct it at a minority for a political advantage. This anger goes beyond normal anger because the issues that these individuals are facing every single day suddenly becomes tied to minorities. Secondly, they change permission mechanisms because they make these views mainstream. That means people think it's okay to be or act racistly because views have been legitimized by others, whether in rallies or in votes. Thirdly, when these populist parties get in power, because they can't implement legitimate policies without alienating a segment of their voter base, instead they're forced to use discriminatory policies to distract from their failure to solve problems. So Trump is forced to try and implement a Muslim ban to distract from the fact that he can't actually solve the problems that his voters are facing without alienating other parts of his voter base. What are the impacts of this? You create a society where minorities live in fear. Fear of being attacked, fear of being spat on on their way to school, fear of not being able to get a job because they're discriminated against in interviews. In extreme cases, their freedom of movement is restricted when they're too afraid to leave their homes. Look, we don't think it's surprising that in the aftermath of the Brexit vote, hate crimes went up 40%, that during the US presidential election, hate crimes against religious and ethnic minorities went up 41%. That's not surprising. And our policy solves this by reducing the ability of

right-wing populists to spread their hatred. My second argument is about how this harms the development of solutions which affect the disaffected. Look, we think there's a legitimate debate to be had over some of these issues, right? We think that disaffective people's concerns unquestionably should be listened to. And there's a conversation that we should have about, for example, how undocumented workers are able to undercut wages. Why does the free speech of right-wing populists actually undermine that debate?
Two reasons. First, because it drags politics to the right-wing populist gutter. Because right-wing populists try to take chunks out of the voters of

centrist parties by doing things like scapegoating minorities. Those centrist parties are forced to move to the right in order to try and keep hold of those voters. The DPP in Denmark was able to pull the Danish Liberal Party right to the point when a party that previously was pro-immigration and asylum seekers ran on a platform of explicitly limiting the number of asylum seekers able to come into that country. The second way that they distort the politics and they harm the development of solutions is because of a lack of nuance in the language that these politicians use. Populist candidates use charisma and shocking language to get free airtime and to show themselves to be saying what the people are thinking. Other parties, in order to compete, are forced to also use shock tactics. So one nation in Australia was able to change the debate on immigration to the point when the yellow peril was a phrase that was actually commonly used. We think you can't have a proper political debate when the language that you're using is un-nuanced, when you're conflating asylum seekers and refugees and immigrants in a way that only populist parties force politics to do. On our side of the house, we're able to escape the noise of populism, we're able to rise above the din, and we're able to have a conversation between centrist politicians which leads to actual, nuanced, legitimate solutions to these problems. In Canada, they were able to have a nuanced conversation about immigration free from the noise of populists, which means they were able to impose an immigration policy that is actually fair and that actually helps the individuals on the ground. Because Team England is the side which protects minorities and actually helps solve the issues which lead populist parties to come about in the first place, I beg you to propose.
Proposition's argument is that right-wing populism is an ideology that can be distilled into five key characteristics.
That's such a scientific dissection.
Honestly, I think it is very demeaning for their side to say that a quarter of all French people and millions of people all around the world are fundamentally nativistic.

They are not politically correct. They just want to lash out at their establishment. I think that what they are doing is to reduce the legitimate viewpoints of all of these people. And I think it's evidence of their liberal arrogance to say that these views should be dismissed from society. We stand against that.

What's our stance? One, we will not impose any restrictions on right-wing populist speech. Two, obviously we don't have to stand for threats to an individual's safety, like death threats, and we will prosecute for acts of violence accordingly. Three, we broadly believe in the value of free speech, even those that are racially tinged. There may come a point where the intent is so malicious and the expressive function of such speech is marginal. In those cases, we will judiciously prosecute for hate speech. The distinction might be porous, and when it is

unclear, we will err on the side of free speech. Four, propositions burden is not just to defend current laws restricting free speech, but they need to defend restricting the entirety of this political ideology, not just the white noise, but also the very legitimate viewpoints that are communicated. We are going to follow three arguments. One, that right-wing populist speech is legitimate and should not be restricted. This deals with the fundamental premise in their case that right-wing populism is something we don't want in society. Two, on the risks of government abuse. And three, my second speaker will explain how they harm political discourse. But before that,

some rebuttals. They first told us that a ban was justified because a democracy is about a balance of rights. But this assumes that their policy is the only way to protect minorities. This is not true, because ethnic and racial minorities can always vote for the Democratic Party. We have democratic checks and balances that are in place. But you know who doesn't have an alternative? It's the millions of disenfranchised workers within the Rust Belt who cannot get another way to express their political views on their political spectrum. We allow for representation. We allow legitimate viewpoints to be expressed. They then say, but these are just distractions. It's just white noise. Right-wing populism isn't solution-oriented.

I think this is honestly very demeaning to see that half the people in America don't want to vote for actual policies. There are very legitimate policies that can be carried out. For instance, immigration quotas, trade protectionism, etc. It's not just all white noise. They then talk to us about how

we may instill fear in minorities. Now, a person's response to such speech could be fear, but it could also be one of moral indignation. And there are many reasons to suggest why moral indignation is the more likely response rather than feeling threatened. The reason for this is because the cost of expressing free speech in the status quo is very low. A lot of this speech happens within social media, so these are people who agree with you, etc. There's a reason why when many African Americans listen to Trump's tweet, the way they respond is not of fear or threat, but they respond by retweeting anti-Trump messages and having them shared and affirmed by people who share their beliefs. Before I move on, yes? Do you support restrictions on hate speech, slander, or incitement to violence when spread by right-wing populists? And if not, why not? I just told you my policy as to why, at a certain point, where if it's so egregious and the intent is so malicious and there's very marginal expressive function, we think we will censor those, but we think for the vast majority of right-wing populist speech, it is not like that. That's a majority burden you have to prove.

The second argument was about discourse. The fundamental premise here is of right-wing populist speech, it is not like that. That's a majority burden you have to prove.
